We provide axioms that guarantee a category is equivalent to that of continuous linear functions between Hilbert spaces. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the mathematical foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a variety of hosts, including humans. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian species. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

The ability of a virus to antagonize the host immune response is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and propagate in their host. In this study, we describe a mechanism by which SARS-CoV-2, the causative agent of the COVID-19 pandemic, is able to antagonize the antiviral action of IFN. Our results reveal a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a deeper understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to antagonize the host immune response and may lead to the development of new strategies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1 channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1 is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These results suggest that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. We show that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the future, even if the mean yield increases. This increase in variability will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses in the major maize-exporting countries, and it will increase the probability of global food price spikes. These results highlight the need for investments in breeding maize varieties that are more heat tolerant.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of large herbivores in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results also highlight the need for more comprehensive species-level identification methods to understand the role of niche partitioning in the ecology of large herbivores. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off or furloughed workers, and that the majority of businesses expect to close within 3 mo. Moreover, many businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Finally, many businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act loans, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective sinks of the plastic debris on the surface of the open ocean. The fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has increased exponentially. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased since the 1950s, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a phase II clinical trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. In a mouse model of multiple system atrophy (MSA), a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder, we show that VX-765 is able to reduce the load of α-syn aggregates in the striatum, to preserve tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra, and to prevent motor deficits. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA. This study also highlights the potential of VX-765 to be used in a clinical trial in MSA patients. The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the flow of blood, the exchange of oxygen and nutrients between the blood and the tissues, and the response to inflammation. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to respond to a wide variety of stimuli. This paper describes the structure of the endothelium and the communication between the cells. The endothelium is a small-world network, which means that the network is both locally and globally efficient. The network is also scale-free, which means that the number of connections between the cells is not evenly distributed.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated a huge amount of data, which are critical for understanding the spread of the disease, for tracking the impact of public health interventions, and for informing public health decision-making. We describe the data sources and signals in the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to many of these data at a fine geographic resolution. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. We demonstrate that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API are useful for tracking COVID activity, and for augmenting traditional public health reporting. The API and software packages are available for download at https://github.com/COVIDcast/covidcast-api. This work provides a valuable resource for researchers and public health decision-makers.

This work provides a structural explanation for the functional coupling between the inactivation gate and the activation gate in potassium channels. The results of this study may also be relevant to the understanding of the structural basis of the allosteric coupling between the inactivation gate and the selectivity filter in other ion channels.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is influenced by the host and its environment. The role of the host in shaping the microbiome is well established, but the role of the microbiome in shaping the host is less clear. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We find that anaerobic fungi synthesize a variety of natural products, which could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome. This study provides a foundation for future research on the role of anaerobic fungi in the regulation of the gut microbiome.

Social dominance is a key feature of social groups, but whether personality traits may predispose individuals to a particular rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We provide evidence that high-anxious animals are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat and that this is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We also show that nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3, enhances brain energy metabolism and prevents the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious individuals. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This paper presents a general framework for the design of multifunctional structures with programmable mechanical responses. The framework is based on the inverse design of composite materials and structures, which is a new field of research that aims to design materials and structures with desired properties by solving inverse problems. The inverse design is performed by a machine-learning algorithm, which is trained by the properties of a large number of materials and structures. The inverse design is then applied to synthesize composite materials and structures with desired properties. The synthesized materials and structures are then fabricated into devices with programmable mechanical responses. The framework can be extended to design multifunctional structures with programmable behaviors under various external stimuli. The framework can be used to design multifunctional structures with programmable mechanical responses for various applications.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development in vertebrates. In this study, we show that the IGF2BP1 protein, which is involved in the regulation of mRNA translation, is a key regulator of the timing of hemoglobin expression in humans. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal liver and is down-regulated in the adult bone marrow. In addition, we show that IGF2BP1 is expressed in the erythroid cells of the adult bone marrow, and that overexpression of IGF2BP1 in these cells results in a reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like pattern. These results suggest that IGF2BP1 is a key regulator of the timing of hemoglobin expression in humans. This study also provides a potential mechanism for the evolution of hemoglobin expression in vertebrates. (Show more)

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, in cancer cells. This resistance is mediated by activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which, in turn, promotes lipogenesis through SREBP1/SCD1-mediated pathways. We show that this resistance can be overcome by mTORC1 inhibition, and that this combination therapy is effective in preclinical models of cancer. These findings suggest that targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway may be a promising strategy for overcoming ferroptosis resistance in cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is a major risk factor for cardiovascular disease, and the treatment of hypertension is a major public health issue. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the mechanisms of action of LCCBs are not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) through a mechanism that is independent of the L-type Ca2+ channel. Our findings reveal a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. This study may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of hypertension and cardiovascular disease. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that transformed forest management in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP has not been successful in reversing the decline of older-forest–associated bird species. Our findings highlight the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and the problem can be addressed by the rational design of new antibiotics. In this study, we present a computational approach for the design of new antibiotics. The approach is based on the prediction of the solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity of acylide antibiotics to the ribosome. The best candidate, which is synthetically more accessible, exhibits higher solubility and binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active than telithromycin, is tested in vitro and in vivo. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The approach presented here can be used to design new antibiotics for other targets and for other antibiotics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We introduce a new network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The proposed architecture is based on a simple idea of using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for many image-processing problems.

The evolution of the African continent has been shaped by the transport of moisture in the tropics. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. Our results show that the transport of moisture in the tropics has a profound influence on the evolution of the African continent. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. The transport of moisture in the tropics has a profound influence on the evolution of the African continent.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that the use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime can have important effects on sleep, including delaying the circadian clock, suppressing melatonin, and reducing the ability to fall asleep. These effects may have important implications for performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is one of the most enigmatic events in the Earth’s climate record. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of the YDB samples is consistent with terrestrial sources. The Os in the spherules is likely derived from a source in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. The Os isotopic composition of the spherules is consistent with a source in the Quebecia terrain, which is 1.5 Ga old. The Os in the spherules is likely terrestrial in origin.
We report that the expression of CTLA-4 in adult mice is essential for the development of a number of autoimmune diseases, and that this is not only restricted to the early stages of the disease.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset to resolve the evolutionary history of beetles, including the origins of plant feeding and the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was shaped by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivores following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable digestion of plant cell walls. These results have implications for understanding the evolution of insects and plants. View Full-Text

The ability of a virus to evade the immune system and the neutralizing antibodies is a major obstacle to the development of effective vaccines and treatments. Here, we demonstrate the utility of a deep learning algorithm in the optimization of an antibody that is effective against SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our algorithm can be used to improve the binding affinity of an antibody to a target, and can be applied to other protein molecules. Our optimized antibody can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work highlights the power of deep learning in the optimization of protein molecules. It also provides a potential solution to the problem of the emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants. We report the results of a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE). We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of technology and the development of intelligence.

The APOE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) susceptibility. APOE isoform is associated with AD risk in a multiplicative manner, meaning that the presence of two copies of the APOE4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold. However, the mechanisms by which APOE isoform influences AD risk are not known. Here, we show that APOE isoform regulates the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, which is a major process of normal synaptic turnover and turnover of senescent synapses. These studies suggest that APOE4 may be associated with defective astrocytic phagocytic capacity, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses and enhances synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. Thus, APOE isoform may be a key factor in AD pathogenesis. This study also provides a mechanism for the protective effect of APOE2, which may be associated with increased rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. This mechanism may be relevant to the clinical observation that APOE2 is associated with a reduced risk of AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is the densest part of the planet. It is a key part of the Earth's interior structure and dynamics. However, the formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. The present work provides a new perspective on the inner core formation, which is a two-step process. The first step is the nucleation of the bcc phase of iron, which is the stable phase at the inner core temperature and pressure. The second step is the growth of the bcc phase into the present inner core. This mechanism provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The present work also provides a new perspective on the structure and anisotropy of the inner core. View Full-Text

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain function are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use leads to reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased craving. These findings highlight the need to investigate the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain function.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s mechanisms for comprehending it are poorly understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks for language processing also provide the best account of brain activity during language comprehension in humans. Our results provide computational evidence for a fundamental role of predictive coding in the language comprehension mechanisms of the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a very successful approach to machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. This paper shows that the instability of DL is not a general property of machine learning, but rather a property of DL. We prove that there are problems in machine learning where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there are no algorithms that can train such a NN. This is a fundamental result that will help us understand the limits of machine learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a major public health crisis. It has led to a large number of deaths and has had a devastating impact on the global economy. The pandemic is also a major source of public debate. In this context, it is important to critically assess the role of psychology in the spread of misinformation and the development of public opinion. In this paper, we discuss the role of psychology in the spread of misinformation and the development of public opinion. We argue that the COVID-19 pandemic is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study—undermining an experiment’s methodology while, ironically, still supporting its conclusion.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two species of bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which causes the disease in the peripheral nervous system, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes the disease in the skin. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two species are remarkably similar, and that they have retained many of the same functions. This suggests that they are still able to cause disease, and that they have not lost the ability to cause disease.

The dynamics of entanglement and entropy in quantum many-body systems is a central topic of current research. In this work, we provide a complete description of the dynamics of entanglement in the space–time scaling limit, which is the relevant limit for the study of quantum quenches. Our result is based on a combination of integrability and quasiparticle concepts, which allow us to describe the entanglement dynamics in terms of a set of excitations. We check our result for the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg chain, and we find excellent agreement with numerical data. Our work provides a powerful framework for the study of the dynamics of entanglement in quantum many-body systems.

The development of a vaccine against COVID-19 is a global priority. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is currently in clinical development. The vaccine, named COVI-VAC, is based on a temperature-sensitive live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 strain. The vaccine candidate is easy to manufacture, has a large safety margin, and is highly protective in a relevant hamster model.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. It has been responsible for the deaths of millions of people in Europe during the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries), including the Black Death (1346–1353). In this study, we show that human ectoparasites, such as fleas and lice, were the primary vectors of plague during this period. This finding challenges the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. Our results are based on a mathematical model, which can be used to study the historical spread of plague in Europe. We hope that our findings will contribute to a better understanding of the history of plague and its impact on human societies.

In this study, we show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the cognitive capacity of animals. TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. Here we show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Thus, TRAP1 may be a promising target for cancer therapy. (Show more)

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the actin cytoskeleton. It is involved in a variety of processes, including cell migration, cell division, and cell differentiation. However, the mechanism by which ADF regulates actin dynamics is not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF can induce a mechanical torque on actin filaments, which enhances the severing of filaments that are held in a twisted conformation. This mechanism is critical for ADF to sever highly connected filament networks, such as those found in cell-cell junctions. Our results provide a mechanism for how the cytoskeleton can be regulated by mechanical forces. This mechanism may be important for understanding how cells respond to mechanical stimuli. Our findings may also have implications for understanding the role of mechanical forces in human diseases. (Show more)

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. This study shows that fructose ingestion results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and related disorders.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique, with a recent arrival of Malagasy people, and the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not a homogeneous process. Finally, we show that a few centuries are enough to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, and it is a first step toward a better understanding of the human history of the Indian Ocean. View Full-Text

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This constitutes experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. The results suggest that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social networks, as well as for the study of emotional contagion in the real world.

The presence of chemical modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) is a common feature of the transcriptome. In this study, we show that the presence of one of the most common modifications, pseudouridine (Ψ), in the mRNA sequence can alter the rate of protein synthesis. We also show that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can increase the rate of near-cognate amino acid incorporation into the growing peptide chain. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can alter the rate of protein synthesis, and that this can be a consequence of the ribosome encountering Ψ. These findings have implications for our understanding of the role of mRNA modifications in protein synthesis. (Show more)

We show that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, more favorable lifestyle behaviors, and stronger social relationships. These associations are independent of factors such as socioeconomic status, depressive symptoms, and prosperity. The feeling that life is worthwhile may be a key factor in promoting healthy aging and sustaining social relationships.

The evolution of body size is a central topic in biology. Here, we show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This attractor is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold, and the temperature at which it replicates is an important factor in the severity of the disease. Here, we show that the temperature at which rhinovirus replicates is determined, at least in part, by the host response to infection.

This study demonstrates that the type IV pili of Pseudomonas aeruginosa are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a sensor for the mechanical activity of the surface. This is the first example of a bacterial system that uses pili as a sensor for the mechanical activity of the surface.

This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global insecticide contamination of surface waters. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the SARS-CoV-2 virus has spread to many animal species. Deer are the most abundant cervid in North America, and they are susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection. We report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 RNA in the lymph nodes of free-living deer, and the detection of SARS-CoV-2 RNA in deer during the peak of the COVID-19 pandemic. These findings highlight the potential for SARS-CoV-2 to persist in wildlife and the need for a coordinated “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of the virus. This study also has important implications for the future of the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major problem that is not being addressed. The paper examines the problems of building dams in the developing world and the need to incorporate climate change into the decision-making process. It also discusses the need to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, it proposes innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation of the inflammatory response in AD is not fully understood. Here, we show that neurons, which are the primary cell type in the brain, are capable of producing a variety of potent inflammatory factors, even in the absence of extracellular Aβ plaques and cell death. These findings suggest that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain may be a primary cause of the early inflammatory response in AD, and may be a key factor in the pathogenesis of the disease.

The chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still missing. We present a detailed analysis of the chicken remains from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was practiced in the Southern Levant as early as the fourth century B.C.E. We further demonstrate that the adoption of chickens in European husbandry was preceded by the Southern Levant by at least a century. Our results provide new insights into the history of the chicken and its spread across the Mediterranean world. (Show more)

The folding of a protein is a key process in biology, and the study of its mechanism is a major goal of biophysics. This paper describes a study of the folding of a large protein, which is a challenging task. The protein studied, maltose binding protein, is large, and the folding process is fast. The results show that the folding of the protein is a complex process, with a number of distinct steps. The results also show that the folding of the protein is not random, but proceeds in a well-defined pathway. The results are important for understanding the folding of other proteins. They also suggest that the folding of the protein is not a simple process.

We report the discovery of a new role for a bacterial enzyme, which, in the absence of stress, is known to be involved in the decapping of capped RNAs. We also describe a mechanism for the recognition of capped RNA 5′ termini, which is distinct from the one used by the enzyme in its normal function.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. Although there are several therapeutic options for the treatment of sepsis, there is no specific strategy to restore immune function after sepsis. In this study, we demonstrate that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is an effective strategy to restore immune function in sepsis. Our results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic option for sepsis.

The biomass of all living organisms on Earth is a key quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants. We also highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our analysis reveals that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Thus, the biomass of humans is a key factor in the functioning of the biosphere.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous in contrast to all known models of SOC. We show that our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models and the relation between our model and pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena. We also discuss the implications of our model for the theory of continuous models.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for a wide range of applications, including photonics, electronics, and quantum devices. However, diamond is a brittle material, and its mechanical properties are not fully understood. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly through strain engineering, and that the bandgap of diamond can be fully closed. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This article is protected by copyright. This study describes the structure, antifungal activity, and mode of action of a unique NCR peptide. The structure of the peptide is highly dynamic and disordered, and it exhibits potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. The peptide binds to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro, and it penetrates the fungal cell wall and membrane, followed by accumulation in the cytoplasm and nucleoli of germlings. The mode of action of the peptide is unique and different from other known antifungal compounds. This study provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of NCR peptides and opens up a new avenue for the development of this class of compounds as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the proteome of the male reproductive tract is distinct from that of the female reproductive tract, and we demonstrate that the proteome of the male reproductive tract is distinct from that of the female reproductive tract. We also show that the proteome of the male reproductive tract is distinct from that of the female reproductive tract. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a key player in the blood clotting system. It binds to the platelet surface protein glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) to promote the formation of a platelet plug. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that the A1 domain in VWF can be switched between two states by force, and that this switching is important for the function of VWF. This work provides a mechanism for the pathophysiology of VWD, and suggests that force may be a key regulator of other biological systems. It also provides a method for studying the effects of mutations in VWF, which may lead to new therapies. (Show more)

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, in part because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database of viruses from human samples, which can be used to study the impact of viruses on human health. The database is publicly available, and can be used to study the impact of viruses on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe aerosols and clouds simultaneously. The HSRL is expected to be a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. Thus, these observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of intense interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is important for the survival of life on the planet. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is also important for the evolution of the Earth and its biosphere. This paper presents a method for determining the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow and are the targets of many drugs. Ion channels are also the targets of many diseases. Ion channels are open or closed, and the open probability is the main factor that determines the ion flow. Ion channels have two types of gates, one for fast channel opening/closing and the other for slow inactivation. The relationship between the two types of gates is not clear. We found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 207 million cases and 445,000 deaths in 2017. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. Here, we show that one of the mechanisms used by the parasite to invade the RBC is to alter the biophysical properties of the cell, which in turn reduces the energy barrier to invasion. This study provides a new perspective on the invasion process, suggesting that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion. This study also provides a potential target for the development of new antimalarial drugs. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for a wide range of applications, including photonics, electronics, and quantum devices. However, diamond is a brittle material, and its mechanical properties are not fully understood. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability. This work provides a new route to tailor the properties of diamond, and it is expected to have a significant impact on the development of diamond-based devices.

This study provides evidence that dry air compromises host defense against influenza infection, and that this effect is mediated, at least in part, by the impairment of mucociliary clearance and innate antiviral defense. In addition, we show that exposure to dry air reduces tissue repair and exacerbates disease pathology. These findings have implications for understanding the impact of climate change on the severity of influenza epidemics. (Show more)

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree of nested phrases. However, whether and how the brain builds such structures is largely unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but suddenly increases whenever words can be merged into a phrase. Our results suggest that the brain performs a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More generally, our findings support the idea that the brain uses a bottom-up or left-corner parser to process the incoming language stream. They also provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists. Our results suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is consistent with the idea that the brain is constantly searching for the most efficient representation of the incoming language stream. View Full-Text
We report here the discovery of a mechanism of gene regulation that is likely to be common in vertebrates.

This paper is about the brain circuits that promote overeating. It is about the brain circuits that may contribute to obesity. It is about the brain circuits that may promote the development of obesity. It is about the brain circuits that may promote the development of obesity in the future.

The ability of bacteria to fix atmospheric nitrogen is a key process in the global nitrogen cycle. This process is of great interest for the agricultural production of nitrogen, but also for the production of bioenergy crops and for the production of nitrogen-free food crops. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between bacteria and plants is therefore of great interest for the sustainable production of nitrogen in agriculture. Here, we describe the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis. The system described here can be used as a platform for the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis. This work also represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis.

We study the effectiveness of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise, and the results are not statistically significant. The estimated reductions were largest in communities facing the largest threats. Data from monitoring records and community surveys provide evidence about how the program may affect forest outcomes. Community members perceived that the program’s monitors were new authorities with influence over forest management and that the monitors’ incentivized patrols were substitutes for traditional, unincentivized citizen patrols that suffer from free riding and inhibit timely community detection of and responses to deforestation. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

We show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear the sounds of its prey and predators, and even the sounds of its own kind, by outsourcing its hearing to its web. The spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna, which is more sensitive to sound than the spider itself. The spider can detect the direction and location of the source of the sound, and can even localize the sound to the level of a single thread in the web. The spider can also adjust the size of the web to the changing needs of its hearing. This study provides a unique model for studying extended and regenerative sensing and for designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. It also provides a new perspective on the evolution of hearing in animals. (Show more)

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We also demonstrate that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing anthropogenic particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C warming.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. The development of vaccines is a critical response, and many are in various stages of clinical trials. Here we describe a recombinant protein vaccine candidate that is well-established, proven, and has been used in multiple commercial vaccines. This vaccine candidate is based on a sequence variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) that is engineered to improve manufacturability, affinity, and immunogenicity. The candidate is presented on a virus-like particle, which may improve the stability and immunogenicity of the vaccine. This work provides a potential vaccine candidate that may be used to accelerate the global response to COVID-19. (Show more)

We report on the discovery of a new class of ligands for the ALK/LTK receptor family. We show that the zebrafish ALKALs are able to activate the zebrafish Ltk and human ALK in vitro. We also show that the three zebrafish ALKALs are required for the development of iridophores, pigment cells of neural crest origin. Finally, we show that loss of the zebrafish ALKALs leads to the loss of iridophores in zebrafish larvae and adults. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALKALs in neural crest development and suggest a role for ALKALs in the pathogenesis of neuroblastoma.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it has been responsible for some of the most devastating outbreaks in human history. The emergence of plague from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is a story of rapid evolution and dispersal, and the study of ancient genomes has allowed us to explore this story in unprecedented detail. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct lineage of plague that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. These data provide a unique window into the formative years of plague, and the study of ancient genomes will continue to provide new insights into the history of this devastating pathogen. (Show more)

This work examined the role of the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies. They also have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the 2020 American presidential election.

The management of agricultural lands has a profound impact on the global carbon cycle. In the United States, the conversion of grassland to cropland has released a large amount of carbon to the atmosphere. This study shows that the management of agricultural lands can be used to mitigate this release of carbon. We show that the management of agricultural lands can be used to mitigate this release of carbon. We show that the management of agricultural lands can be used to mitigate this release of carbon.

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans. We then created a web tool, SpillOver, that allows users to explore the results of this analysis. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that many animals seek out in order to obtain pollen and/or seeds. Nectar color is an important cue for animals seeking out the reward, and many species of plants have evolved to produce nectar of a color that is attractive to their preferred pollinators. Here, we show that the color of the nectar of the blood-red plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also show that the alkaloid is attractive to the most likely pollinator of this plant, the gecko Phelsuma geckos. This work demonstrates that the color of the nectar of this plant is a convergently evolved trait, and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a new alkaloid for the chemical world. (Show more)

We present a study of the genetic ancestry of women in Europe during the Early Medieval period. We show that women in Europe at this time had a very high genetic heterogeneity, and that this heterogeneity was not limited to the modern European population. In addition, we show that women had a genetic ancestry that was not limited to Europe, and that they also differed in visible characteristics. This study highlights the importance of female-biased migration in shaping the genetic landscape of Europe.

The receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5 were investigated. The results suggest that the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses are dependent on the species of the host. These results provide insights into the origin of Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) and the transmission of bat coronaviruses to humans. They also suggest that bat coronaviruses pose a threat to human health because of their ability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We describe the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform for pathogen surveillance in a resource-scarce setting. We demonstrate that mNGS can be used to identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers in a periurban population in Cambodia. We also show that mNGS can be used to identify the presence of HIV and other coinfections in febrile patients. This study highlights the potential of mNGS for pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings, and the need for coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance to better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. This will enable deployment of rapid public health response. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The human genome is replicated in a complex process that requires the concerted action of multiple proteins. One of the most important steps in the replication of the lagging strand is the formation of the pol δ holoenzyme, which is responsible for the synthesis of the Okazaki fragments. In this study, we have developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that the pol δ holoenzyme is not as stable as previously thought and that it dissociates from PCNA while replicating DNA. This behavior has profound implications on the synthesis of the lagging strand in humans.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In the laboratory, the evolution of life can be studied by in vitro evolution of RNA molecules. In this paper, we describe the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA, synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, and amplify RNA by more than 10,000-fold. This work provides a foundation for the study of the origin of life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over the course of 10 y. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of other cities and other types of urban change. We hope that it will be useful to urban scholars and practitioners.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex, and the treatment is still in the stage of clinical trial. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, can reduce the mortality of severe and critical COVID-19 patients, and may be a potential treatment for COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but at high concentrations it is toxic. The ability of fungi to regulate copper homeostasis is critical for their survival in the environment and in the human body. Here we describe the existence of a fungal natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. This work demonstrates the existence of a previously unknown role for eukaryotic natural products in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the ability of fungi to mediate interactions with competing microbes. This work also provides a model for the study of the role of natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis in fungi and other organisms. (Show more)

The formation of the Martian surface is a complex process, and the history of the planet is not fully understood. The study of the chemical composition of the surface and the processes that formed it is critical to understanding the evolution of the planet.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agriculture, and the frequency of late-spring frosts is increasing in many regions of the Northern Hemisphere. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is linked to the evolutionary history of the species, and that the resistance strategies of trees are adapted to the local frost risk. Our findings can be used to predict the future evolution of frost risk, and to inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of these diseases is not well understood. Here, we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings may have implications for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

We report a method to rapidly produce induced astrocytes from living ALS patients. These cells can be expanded in culture and used for disease modeling and drug screening. We show that astrocytes derived from ALS patients are toxic to motor neurons, and this toxicity is shared between patients and familial ALS mice. This method will enable rapid screening of drugs for the treatment of ALS. It will also allow the study of the role of astrocytes in ALS pathogenesis and the development of new therapies. This study will also help to understand the role of astrocytes in other neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

This study provides a unique example of a pathogen using a host protein to alter the gut microbiota of its vector. The study also provides a model for how pathogens may use host proteins to alter the gut microbiota of other arthropod vectors.

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds and the origin of the modern bird form is a major area of research. However, the study of the origins of the avian body plan has been hindered by the lack of knowledge of the earliest members of the group. Here, we describe a new basal member of the group, which provides important information about the origin of the avian body plan.

We show that the stratospheric water vapor feedback is a real physical process, and that it is significantly larger than previously thought. This feedback is important for understanding the climate sensitivity of the Earth, and it is also important for understanding the evolution of the climate in the past.

The presence of blue-green tissues in vertebrates is a unique feature of the animal kingdom. This phenomenon, called chlorosis, is associated with the presence of high concentrations of biliverdin, a pigment that is normally found in the blood. In this study, we describe the biochemical and molecular basis of chlorosis in anurans, the most widespread group of frogs and toads. We also show that chlorosis has evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of anurans, and that the presence of biliverdin-binding serpins (BBSs) is a key factor in the evolution of chlorosis. BBSs are a member of the serpin superfamily, which is the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the presence of BBSs, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. This study also presents evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis. View Full-Text

This study provides evidence that the hypoxia-induced expression of ALKBH5, a m6A demethylase, is a mechanism by which breast cancer cells adapt to hypoxia. ALKBH5 expression is increased in breast cancer, and ALKBH5-deficient mice are more sensitive to hypoxia. ALKBH5 expression is increased in breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs), and ALKBH5 knockdown in MDA-MB-231 cells significantly reduced their capacity for tumor initiation as a result of reduced numbers of BCSCs. Thus, ALKBH5 expression is a mechanism by which breast cancer cells adapt to hypoxia, and may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. It is also one of the most fragile. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. This paper reports the results of a study of 365 parchment samples, including 72 pocket Bibles, using a simple and objective method that identifies the animal origin of the parchment. The results suggest that the source of the parchment was not necessarily the use of abortive or newborn animals.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical to understanding the causes of the event and its impact on the evolution of life on Earth. The age model presented here is based on the age of the Permian-Triassic boundary, which marks the onset of the extinction.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the presence of inflammation in the intestinal mucosa. IBD is a complex disease, and the exact pathogenesis is still unclear. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays an important role in the pathogenesis of IBD. We generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. Our study provides a new target for IBD treatment, which could be beneficial to the treatment of IBD. This study also provides a new perspective for the treatment of IBD. View Full-Text

We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein in complex with the receptor ACE2 at 8.3 Å resolution. The structure of the spike protein is highly dynamic, and the structure presented here is representative of the state of the protein at the time of data collection. The structure of the spike protein provides a framework for understanding the mechanism of infection and for the design of vaccines and therapeutics.

We study the existence of equilibria in repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs. We show that, for a large class of games, every player has an equilibrium strategy, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite. The proof is based on a new result on the existence of equilibria in stochastic games.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a reduction in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry, and they are the starting point for the study of the properties of compounds. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become electron acceptors. We show that our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales are explicative and predictive. Our results are of fundamental importance for the understanding of the chemical properties of atoms under pressure. They are also of great importance for the understanding of the properties of compounds under pressure.

We show that changes in human demography can have a large impact on the global fire regime, and that this can have a significant impact on climate. We find that, although climate change has already warmed the fire regime, changes in human demography have suppressed global fire activity, and that this has offset some of the warming. However, the effect of fire on climate is most effective under lower emission scenarios, highlighting the importance of reducing emissions to avoid further warming. Our results suggest that fire suppression and ignitions can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, and that climate change may be less effective in mitigating future warming if fire suppression and ignitions continue.

This study provides a new perspective on the role of host-derived nutrients in the regulation of the activities of symbionts. We show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is a key factor in the maintenance of the mutualism. This glycan is provided only at night, when the host is quiescent, and is catabolized by the symbiont only at night, when the host is active. This glycan-driven rhythmicity of the host and symbiont activities is essential for the maintenance of the symbiosis.

We present a method for identifying latent topics in text data. Our method is based on advances in machine learning and word embedding, and it is flexible enough to be applied to a wide range of domains. We apply our method to the National Violent Death Reporting System, a database of violent death incidents. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to a wide range of domains, and it can be extended to other types of data. We believe that our method will be useful to researchers in many fields.

The Black Death, the deadliest epidemic in human history, originated in Asia and spread to Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. We show that the climate conditions in Asia, where the disease originated, were favorable for the survival of Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes plague, for centuries before the first plague outbreaks in Europe. We also show that the climate conditions in Europe were favorable for the survival of the bacterium in Asia, and that the first plague outbreaks in Europe were the consequence of repeated reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia. Our results suggest that the climate conditions in Asia were the main driver of the spread of plague in Europe. This study provides evidence for the importance of climate change in the spread of plague in Europe. It also highlights the importance of the ancient Silk Road system in the spread of plague in Europe. (Less Less)

We show that a densovirus is the most likely cause of asteroid mass mortality. The virus is present in the environment and in museum specimens, and it has been present on the North American Pacific Coast for at least 72 y.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a devastating disease with a poor prognosis. The identification of targets for treatment is therefore of great importance. In this study, we show that the IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. Furthermore, we show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling is effective in suppressing the proliferation of primary AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study also provides a proof of principle for the use of antibodies as a treatment for AML. Thus, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. This study may therefore have important implications for the treatment of AML in the future. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. The island is home to a unique Bantu language, which is the only language in the world that is spoken by a majority of the population. The island is also home to a unique genetic diversity, which is the result of a combination of a long history of human settlement and a unique geography. We present a detailed analysis of the genetic diversity of the Malagasy population, which is the largest population study of Madagascar to date. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, which arrived on the island independently. In addition, we find that the genetic structure of the population is influenced by the geography of the island. This study provides a detailed picture of the genetic diversity of the Malagasy population, which is a unique population in terms of its language and its geography. This study also provides a detailed picture of the history of Madagascar, which is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. View Full-Text

Bacteria are able to regulate gene expression at the level of the RNA transcript. In some cases, the RNA encodes a protein that can interact with the protein encoded by the gene of interest. In this study, we describe a small RNA that encodes a protein and demonstrates that the protein can interfere with the function of the gene of interest. This is the first example of a small RNA that encodes a protein and demonstrates the importance of considering the protein encoded by the RNA in the regulation of gene expression.

The ability of a virus to evade the immune system and the neutralizing antibodies is a major obstacle to the development of effective vaccines and treatments. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to improve the neutralizing activity of an antibody against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that can improve the antibody’s neutralizing activity against the Delta variant. Our optimized antibody can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.
