Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status, but their assessments are subjective and categorical. We show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We demonstrate that the resulting Crop Condition Index is more accurate than official forecasts released midseason by the US Department of Agriculture. The proposed methodology can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. The proposed approach can be easily extended to other crops and countries.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it enables the binding of linguistic features over time. Our model provides a neurobiological substrate for the storage of information in working memory, and it may be a general mechanism for the integration of information in the brain.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is a key uncertainty in our understanding of the future evolution of the carbon cycle. In this paper, we present the results of a global synthesis of soil respiration measurements, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of experimental warming. Our analysis reveals that soil respiration does not increase in response to warming in all biomes, and that the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration decreases with increasing temperature. These results highlight the importance of regional differences in soil respiration responses to climate change, and the need for further research to understand the mechanisms behind these differences.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key indicator of the evolutionary history of the host organism. The study of the molecular evolution of the plastid genome is therefore a powerful tool for the study of the evolution of the host organism. The study of the molecular evolution of the plastid genome is therefore a powerful tool for the study of the evolution of the host organism.

The impact of anthropogenic climate change on the probability of occurrence of extreme droughts is a key concern for the future of southwestern South Africa. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in the region. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work highlights the need for urgent mitigation efforts to reduce the risk of future droughts in the region. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion, the Trinity test, has been a source of fascination for the scientific community. The discovery of a new quasicrystal in the red trinitite, the oldest known anthropogenic material, provides a unique window into the history of the discovery of quasicrystals.

(Bacterio)chlorophylls are the light harvesting pigments of oxygenic photosynthesis. The biosynthesis of these pigments is one of the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key feature of these pigments, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This paper describes the evolution of the enzymes that catalyze this reaction, and their role in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease, and astrocytes produced key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a rationale for the use of a combination of drugs to treat MS. We show that the probability of drought has increased in California over the past century, and that this increase is attributable to anthropogenic warming. Our results have important implications for the future of California, as well as for the rest of the western United States and the globe.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for understanding the causal paths that lead to autism symptoms and may facilitate the development of new approaches for the treatment of autism. This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

We report on a series of patients with Stormorken syndrome, a rare disorder of store-operated Ca2+ entry, and on a series of patients with Stormorken-like syndrome, a rare disorder of store-operated Ca2+ entry that is associated with a milder phenotype. We also describe the molecular basis of these disorders, which are caused by mutations in two genes that are involved in store-operated Ca2+ entry.

Bats are the only mammals that can live in caves, and they are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system of bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. These findings may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of viral diseases in humans and animals. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the cell cycle is fueled by the one-carbon units provided by the folate cycle. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase, which converts serine to glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. We show that this inhibitor is effective in cancer cells, and that the one-carbon unit donor formate is a potent rescue. We also show that the cancer cell-line screen is dominated by B-cell lines, and that one of the most sensitive cell lines is a diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This latter finding is important, because this lymphoma is notoriously difficult to treat. Thus, we have identified a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This deficiency is rooted in defective glycine import, and thus a glycine import inhibitor is a potential therapeutic. This work is a step toward the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics.

We show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS are supersaturated in motor neurons, but not in other tissues. This suggests that the presence of these proteins in inclusions is a consequence of a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in motor neurons, and not merely a consequence of the presence of a large number of native interaction partners. This observation may have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for ALS.

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The results are expected to be broadly applicable to other systems of cold atoms and photons. The photonic crystal system is a promising platform for many-body physics and quantum engineering. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous, is a major contribution to the understanding of the evolution of the angiosperms. The study of Montsechia has been hampered by the lack of a detailed description of the plant. The study presented here provides a detailed description of the plant, including its anatomy and reproduction. The study also provides a detailed analysis of the position of Montsechia in the angiosperm tree of life.

The study of ancient viruses is hampered by the lack of ancient viral sequences. Here we present the first ancient viral sequences, which are from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

We show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with the IPCC AR5 model projections. We also show that the acceleration is not due to changes in the rate of satellite altimeter data calibration.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, pain prevalence has increased with age for each successive birth cohort, and that the increase has been steeper for those born after 1950. The increase in pain is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. Instead, it fits a more general pattern seen in the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If this trend continues, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of a key enzyme intermediate. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a mechanistic view of enzyme reactions, and it provides a model for the application of this approach to other enzyme reactions.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high case fatality rate highlights the need for the development of effective antiviral therapies. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study provides a new perspective on the role of host-derived nutrients in the regulation of the activities of symbionts in animal–microbe associations. We show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a specific, cyclic manner, is required for the maintenance of a stable symbiosis. This glycan is consumed by the symbiont only at night, when the host organ is used for light production. The consumption of this glycan by the symbiont is also required for the periodic acidification of the host organ, which enhances the level of oxygen available to the symbionts. This study suggests that the provision of specific nutrients, whose catabolism modulates the conditions in the habitat of the symbionts, may be a general mechanism for the regulation of the activities of symbionts in animal–microbe associations. DNA alkylation is one of the major causes of DNA damage and is involved in the development of a variety of human diseases. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe pneumonia in humans. The virus infects human lung cells by binding to cell receptors and by undergoing sequential proteolysis, first to release the S glycoproteins, and second to facilitate cell membrane fusion. Here, we show that the first cleavages of the S glycoproteins are required for MERS-CoV infection of human lung cells, and that the second cleavages are required for infection of other cell types. These findings suggest that the first cleavages expand the virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

This paper provides evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 40%. This is a large effect, and it is achieved with a simple change to the catering system. The results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets could have a significant impact on population health and the environment. The results also suggest that it may be possible to achieve this increase without a significant impact on overall sales. This is an important finding, as it suggests that it may be possible to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets without reducing sales overall. The results also suggest that it may be possible to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets without increasing the proportion of meat meals purchased.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to engage the extracellular space. Here we report the first comprehensive analysis of the surfaceome in cancer cells, and show that the surfaceome is remodeled in a cell autologous fashion by oncogenes. We also report a method for the analysis of the glycoproteome, which is a major component of the surfaceome, and show that oncogenes have a profound effect on the glycoproteome. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is expected to be of interest to the cancer research community.

The 2020 presidential election is the first in which the United States will use a mail-in voting system on a large scale. Many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand vote-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the COVID-19 pandemic.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has led to millions of infections and thousands of deaths. The virus has a large number of mutations, and the rate of mutation is increasing. The virus has also evolved a number of mechanisms to evade the host immune system and to avoid the immune system of the host. In this paper, we describe the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein, which is a key protein in the evasion of the immune system.

Cerebral edema is a common and potentially life-threatening illness, but the mechanisms underlying its development are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats, and that this is mediated, at least in part, by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex to trigger the expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1), leading to cerebral edema. These findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the pathogenesis of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

We live in an era of big data and complex statistical modeling. The size of the data sets and the complexity of the models make it difficult to assess the significance of the results. We describe a new approach to this problem, which we call selective inference. It is based on the idea that we should set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we find. We illustrate the approach using forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We hope that this will help readers to understand the new challenges and opportunities that big data and complex modeling present.

The study of endothelial cell (EC) development is important for understanding the process of EC differentiation and for the development of new therapies for vascular diseases. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can induce the differentiation of human adult skin fibroblasts into functional ECs (ETVECs). The ETV2-induced EC differentiation is mediated by the activation of transcription factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1. The ETV2-induced EC differentiation can be used for the generation of ECs for transplantation therapy and for the development of vascular networks for the regeneration of damaged organs. This study provides a new approach for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. (Show more)

We report the discovery of a new class of ligands for the orphan RTKs anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk). We show that these ligands are essential for the development of the zebrafish iridophore system, a pigment-producing tissue. This discovery has implications for our understanding of the function of these receptors in vivo and for the development of new therapeutics.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex metabolic disorder, which is characterized by insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction. Although the role of STING in the regulation of insulin resistance has been extensively studied, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency in β-cells impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, which was associated with the down-regulation of Pax6. These findings revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study may provide a new perspective for the treatment of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which is an evolutionary advantage but complicates the packaging of the genome into the virion. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments, which is required for optimal viral replication. This interaction is sequence dependent and favors copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. Our results indicate that the interaction between viral RNA segments is a mechanism for selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. The lack of conservation of this interaction among influenza A viruses might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging and may lead to the development of new strategies for the control of influenza A virus infections. (Show more)

The study of the vascular system is one of the most important areas of biomedical research. The vascular system is responsible for the transport of oxygen, nutrients, and other essential molecules to the tissues and the removal of metabolic waste products. The vascular system is also responsible for the regulation of blood pressure and the maintenance of blood flow. The vascular system is a complex system, and the regulation of blood flow is a critical process. The regulation of blood flow is essential for the proper functioning of the vascular system.

Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-started wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in the future. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control, but their direct molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. The model is used to estimate the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual animals, and to assess the effect of an antiviral treatment on the time to undetectable plasma viral load. We find that the model is able to capture the main features of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV, and that the model predictions can be used to guide the design of clinical trials of antiviral drugs. The model can be used to assess the effect of different treatment strategies, and to predict the effect of different drug dosages and schedules. The model can also be used to assess the effect of different treatment start times, and to predict the effect of different treatment start times on the time to undetectable plasma viral load. Coral reefs are among the most valuable ecosystems on Earth, but they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the processes involved in the early stages of bleaching and may help us to predict the fate of coral reefs in a changing climate.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a barrier to the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the mounting of immune responses, and the prevention of systemic infections. In this study, we show that the intestinal epithelium is a dynamic tissue that is constantly in contact with the microbiome. We also show that the microbiome can trigger a regenerative response in the epithelium, which in turn can stimulate tumor growth. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of the JNK pathway to maintain the integrity of the intestinal epithelium and host–microbe homeostasis. It also identifies a mechanism by which the microbiome can influence the development of intestinal tumors. These findings may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of intestinal tumors. View Full-Text

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, and the response to chemotherapy is an important determinant of the outcome of the disease. In this study, we show that chemotherapy enhances the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 in breast cancer cells, and that ROR1 expression is associated with the development of breast cancer stemness. Furthermore, we show that targeting ROR1 with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab is effective in reducing the expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, and in inhibiting the development of breast cancer PDXs. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may be an effective strategy for improving the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of deglaciation is often dated by the timing of the Mount Tambora volcanic eruption, which occurred in April 1815 and is known as the year without a summer. However, the start of deglaciation is not well constrained, and the timing of the start of deglaciation is important for understanding the causes of the last ice age.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, freshwater fisheries are often overlooked in global assessments of fisheries and biodiversity. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that the majority of catches come from regions with high levels of human population density and river discharge. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, our analysis reveals that fishing in regions with high biodiversity is often unsustainable, highlighting the need for improved management of inland fisheries. Our data can be used to improve the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable Mo-based oxide with a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water is realized. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. We report a form of regeneration in the adult nervous system that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of a sensory dendrite, and it is enhanced by disrupting calcium channels and elevating cAMP. We also show that this form of regeneration is triggered by sensory activity, and it is blocked by inactivation of the NDR kinase, which is required for sensory activity-dependent regeneration. These findings suggest that this form of regeneration is a powerful platform for gene discovery in neuronal regeneration. Moreover, they suggest that the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity is controlled by a form of conditioning that is similar to lesion conditioning in the mammalian CNS.

The process of recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome, and its rate is a key factor in the evolution of a species. However, the spatial distribution of recombination across the genome is poorly understood. Here, we describe the spatial pattern of recombination in a flowering plant, and we find that it is similar to that in yeast and in mice.

The resting state network (RSN) organization of the human brain is a key feature of the functional architecture of the brain. Here, we show that the RSN organization can be mapped to the metabolic activity of the brain, providing a direct measure of the brain’s total activity. This approach can be used to identify and validate reproducible RSN topographies in healthy and disease populations. Furthermore, we show that the RSN organization is altered in Parkinson’s disease, and that this alteration can be partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. Finally, we show that the RSN organization is altered in Alzheimer’s disease, and that this alteration is already present at diagnosis. These results provide a new approach to the study of the brain’s resting organization.

This paper is about the structure of the 5′ end of RNA. It is about the 5′ cap, and it is about the 5′ end of tRNA. It is also about the 5′ end of NAD+ and the 5′ end of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD).

We show that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at specific loci persist during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) in people with diabetes, and that these loci are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy during the DCCT on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. These findings may also have implications for the epigenetic regulation of other metabolic diseases.
This study provides a new insight into the role of FSIP1 in the drug sensitivity of TNBC. Our findings may aid in the design of TNBC therapies.

Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in a significant proportion of alcohol-dependent subjects, and that this alteration is associated with the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence, and this alteration is associated with the gut barrier. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile compounds, many of which are nitrogenous. The biosynthesis of these compounds is poorly understood, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in the flavor of tomato fruit is unknown. Here, we describe the discovery of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also describe the discovery of a pathway for the biosynthesis of these compounds, which is unique to tomato. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of nitrogenous volatiles in plants and will be of interest to researchers in a wide range of disciplines. (Show more)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. We also show that the temperature response of this relationship is mediated by changes in species interactions. Our results highlight the importance of considering the effects of climate change on biodiversity in the context of ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to reflect different aspects of the environment. However, the anatomical and functional organization of these cell types is not fully understood. Here, we used a novel method to record from a large number of neurons in the MEC while the mice freely explored an open field. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be responsible for the formation of a mental map of the environment, are anatomically segregated from other cell types. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of the MEC and its cell types and will be useful for future studies of the functional roles of these cell types. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is not only important for the flowering of the host, but also for the flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine-producing neurons of the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by a loss of dopamine-containing neurons, but the mechanisms underlying this loss are not fully understood. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized system of neurons in the substantia nigra that may be involved in the pathogenesis of the disease.

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they click. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart, and its function is critical for the normal heart rate and blood pressure. However, the SAN can become dysfunctional in a variety of diseases, including heart failure, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation. In this study, we show that the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 is expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN, and its deletion in mice leads to a reduction in Ca2+ stores and a loss of SAN automaticity. These results suggest that STIM1 is a key regulator of SAN Ca2+ stores and function. Our findings may lead to the development of new therapies for the treatment of heart failure and atrial fibrillation. (Show more)

The beneficial effects of silicon (Si) on plant growth and stress tolerance have been well documented, but the role of Si in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been explored. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by an increase in silicon accumulation and by priming of jasmonate (JA)-mediated defense responses. These results suggest that silicon may be used as a tool to enhance plant resistance against insect herbivores. This study also provides a mechanism for the use of silicon in agriculture to improve plant resistance against insect herbivores. (Show more)

This study provides a new view on the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism. It also demonstrates the importance of the enzyme alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism and in the regulation of macrophage function.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This is a new way of thinking about memory in the brain, and it provides a framework for understanding the role of memory in language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a challenging task due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Here, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules to plants, and that the size, shape, and geometry of the DNA nanostructures are the key factors that determine the delivery efficiency. We also show that the delivery of biomolecules to plants is dependent on the location of the attachment site of the biomolecule to the DNA nanostructure. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the delivery of biomolecules to plants in the future.

We show that the nutrient loads from small tributaries of large water bodies are often high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. This suggests that the coastal zone of these water bodies may be more sensitive to nutrient inputs from small watersheds than previously thought. Our findings have important implications for the management of coastal ecosystems, as well as for the design of future monitoring programs.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to a small fraction of the possible chemical states. We find that the dynamics of the network are biased toward states that are extremized with respect to the environmental forcing. We discuss the implications of this result for the dynamics of complex networks of chemical reactions.

The history of carbon (C) perturbation events throughout Earth’s history has provided key insights into how the Earth system responds to abrupt warming. However, most studies focused on short-term warming events superimposed on longer-term greenhouse climate states. Here, we present an integrated proxy (carbon and uranium isotopes and paleo CO2) and multicomponent modeling approach to investigate an abrupt C perturbation and global warming event (∼304 Ma) that occurred during a paleo-glacial state. We report pronounced negative carbon and uranium isotopic excursions coincident with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 partial pressure and a biodiversity nadir. The isotopic excursions can be linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon over a large area and to near 20% of areal extent of seafloor anoxia. Earth system modeling indicates that widespread anoxic conditions can be linked to enhanced thermocline stratification and increased nutrient fluxes during this global warming within an icehouse. This work provides a new perspective on the history of carbon perturbation events and their potential to trigger global warming. It also highlights the potential for the release of organic matter–derived carbon to have played a role in the evolution of life on Earth.

We show that the certification of palm oil production has a causal impact on deforestation in Indonesia. Certification reduced deforestation by 33% from a counterfactual of 9.8 to 6.6% y−1. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocytosis process is essential for the release of proteins and other molecules from the endoplasmic reticulum to the plasma membrane and other organelles. The exocyst complex is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and enhancement of vacuolar trafficking in plants. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a key process in the evolution of animals, and the sex of an individual can have a profound effect on its fitness. In this study, we investigate the effects of sex determination on the body of a single species of fish. We find that the sex of the fish is not just male or female, but rather is a combination of the sex of the fish and the sex of the fish’s parents.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct forms of oxidative stress. The first is the photochemical oxidation of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) by light, which leads to the accumulation of lipofuscin, a complex mixture of oxidized and reduced forms of vitamin A. The second form of oxidative stress is the photochemical oxidation of the photoreceptor cells, which leads to the accumulation of a complex mixture of oxidized and reduced forms of the pigment molecule, A2E. We show that the levels of iron in the retina play a role in both of these processes.

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key factor in the structure of food webs. However, the evolution of predator specialization has been considered an evolutionary dead end. Here we show that the evolution of predator specialization is not only possible, but also common in nature. Our results contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. These findings contribute to our understanding of the evolution of predator specialization and its role in shaping the structure of food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. The fossil record for the hominin hand between 800,000 and 1.8 My old is sparse, and the fossil record for the evolution of the hand in the genus Homo is even sparser. We report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from the Middle Pleistocene that provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the modern human hand.

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the cell cycle is fueled by the one-carbon units provided by the folate cycle. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase, which converts serine to glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. We show that this inhibitor is effective in cancer cells, and that the one-carbon unit donor formate is a potent rescue. We also show that the cancer cell-line screen is dominated by B-cell lines, and that one of these, diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, is uniquely sensitive to inhibition of SHMT. Thus, we have identified a targetable metabolic deficiency of lymphoma. This work provides a platform for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics. (Show more)

This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The study also highlights the need for a more holistic approach to food and nutrition security, which takes into account the role of natural landscapes such as forests in improving people’s diets. This study is also an example of how causal inference can be used to test the impact of deforestation on people’s diets.

The mechanization of agriculture has been a key factor in the success of modern civilization. However, the increase in capacity of farm machinery has come at a cost of increased subsoil compaction, which has been shown to have adverse effects on soil functioning and crop productivity. We show that the global distribution of subsoil compaction risk has increased over the course of modern mechanization, and that the total area of compaction risk is now larger than the area of arable land. This alarming trend calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a second paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
